sn21.1:1.3: Kolita was his personal name, Moggallāna his clan name.
sn21.1:2.7: So-called because of the absence of vitakka and vicāra, which are the precursors of speech (SN 41.6:2.4, MN 44:15.3).
sn21.1:2.8: The verb viharati here and below, and in the parallel passages at SN 40.1ff., uses the aorist and present tenses inconsistently. I take the first passage as historical present, the second as aorist in simple past tense.
sn21.1:2.9: In the Suttas, saññāmanasikārā is only used in negative contexts, but later texts use it in a positive way as well (Ps 1.1:171.5, Pe 8:3.3).
sn21.1:3.5: A series of similar conversations on different states of meditation is found in the Moggallānasaṁyutta (SN 40).
